entry.title: The Funny Thing About Quitting
entry.content:
We were shooting the shit in the gym on Thursday, when the subject of wasted memberships came up. As I’m sure is common in any other type of service with a monthly membership, we apparently have a fair amount of people who pay for an unlimited pass but only show up once every two weeks or so. Or even people who pay for a membership and just don’t show up at all. This isn’t such a big deal at a place where the monthly fee is $10, but for BJJ gyms in metropolitan areas, the costs tend to fall somewhere between $100-$200 / month.

That’s a pretty significant amount of money. So why would people spend it for a service they’re not bothering to use? Sure, there’s a “one year” contract for the gym, but owners tend to be understanding most of the time, and the effort in canceling that is pretty trivial. I think the real barrier is in the way people think about quitting.

When we pick up a hobby and things get serious, it starts working its way into our definitions of ourselves. This is especially true for something like jiu jitsu, which involves a heavy investment and intrinsically comes with rewards like “higher self confidence”, but it also applies to anything from learning a new language to picking up an instrument to experimenting with painting.

So it’s only natural that when life starts getting in the way, we cling onto that image. Maybe we go from every day to only a few times a week. Then once a week. Then once a month. Then “Oh yeah, I’m learning to speak Spanish, but it’s been a few months since I’ve had the chance to practice…” But we rarely ever cross the threshold into consciously declaring that we’ve quit. Are you still really playing the guitar if it’s been six months since you’ve touched it? One year? Three?

Canceling a membership requires the conscious decision that yes, I’ve quit. But we never really seem to cross that point. It’s always one rationalization after another. Perhaps if we’re could be more honest with ourselves, we could save a lot of the resources that that costs us, whether that be a monthly membership fee that could be better put towards something else, or the energy and creativity spent in thinking up justifications for ourselves.

entry.title: New Belt!
entry.content:
Normally I try to keep the “dear diary” factor on the blog low. But in all the bustle of settling back into the east coast with a new work arrangement, I all but forgot about the whole blogging thing until roughly 2 minutes ago. So if you’re one of the ones who reads this for what little informational value I manage to provide, or are otherwise uninterested in participating in this rare bout of masturbatory self-congratulations, here’s your cue.

Still here? So… I got my blue belt in BJJ recently. For anyone unfamiliar, it’s basically the “hurrah, you’re no longer a rookie” rank, and in all seriousness this is one of my prouder moments. Why? Because of all my regular activities, BJJ is the one where I have absolutely no talent whatsoever. Seriously. It took me a solid 2 years to get to this point, and every day of that was spent with the mat being wiped by my face. Ask anyone at the gym: I still get rag-dolled on a regular basis.

Now, as a software developer (and all-around lazy nerd) I have a propensity to approach most problems by a) finding an easier way to do it, b) deciding it’s not worth the time, or c) see (a). It’s an approach that works for software, for games, and probably for most challenges you’re likely to find in the first world. But it’s great having proof that sometimes you just have to show up and grind through and that’s the only way to improve. It’s a reminder that surprisingly often, the only actual obstacle is just you being a giant chicken and unwilling to leave your comfort zone.

So, as the kid who couldn’t do a single push-up and ran a 13 minute mile in school, I’d like to give myself a pat on the back for managing to get this far. And despite all the split lips, swollen fingers, and sprained joints, I sure hope I get a lot farther in the future.

Oh, and… I kind of lied about the lack of material. I had another 52-weeks post lined up, but the experiment failed horribly. I’m just buying time so I can do a second iteration and save SOME face, so… Look forward to that one.
